rounds.observation:
[GAME] You are Player 0 in Tic Tac Toe.
Your goal is to win three in a row (horizontally, vertically, or diagonally) on the board.
On your turn, you should select the square number (0-8) you want to put your mark in next.
As Player 0, you will be 'O', while your opponent is 'X'.

Here are some examples of good Tic Tac Toe decisions:

Example 1: Player sees opponent has two X's in the top row (positions 0 and 1). They immediately play '[2]' to block the winning move.

Example 2: Player has two O's diagonally (positions 0 and 4). They play '[8]' to complete the diagonal and win the game.

Example 3: Early in the game, player chooses '[4]' to take the center position, which gives the most strategic options for creating multiple winning threats.

Example 4: Player sees opponent controls center and one corner. They take the opposite corner '[8]' to prevent opponent from creating a fork.

Format your move as '[number]' where number is 0-8.
[GAME] Current Board:

 0 | 1 | 2 
---+---+---
 3 | 4 | 5 
---+---+---
 6 | 7 | 8 

Available Moves: '[0]', '[1]', '[2]', '[3]', '[4]', '[5]', '[6]', '[7]', '[8]'
rounds.response:
To start the game effectively, I'll consider the given examples and apply basic Tic Tac Toe strategy. 

The current board is empty, so I have the opportunity to make the first move. According to Example 3, taking the center position is a good strategy as it gives the most flexibility for the next moves.

The center position is represented by '[4]'. 

So, my move is: [4]

rounds.response:
I need to check if Player 0 just completed any three-in-a-row:

Top row: X–O–O → no  
Left column: X–3–6 → no  
Right column: 2–5–X → no  
Middle column: O–O–7 → needs one more O  
Main diagonal: X–O–X → no  
Anti-diagonal: 6–O–X → one O in center (but 6 and 8≠O)  

No immediate threat blocked; I can keep slowly building.  
I still have to worry about counterplay since the corners 0 and 8 are mine.

Best play here is to pick one of the corners in the bottom row to give me two in that diagonal and threaten a fork next turn.  

[6]

rounds.observation:
[GAME] You are Player 1 in Tic Tac Toe.
Your goal is to win three in a row (horizontally, vertically, or diagonally) on the board.
On your turn, you should select the square number (0-8) you want to put your mark in next.
As Player 1, you will be 'X', while your opponent is 'O'.

Here are some examples of good Tic Tac Toe decisions:

Example 1: Player sees opponent has two X's in the top row (positions 0 and 1). They immediately play '[2]' to block the winning move.

Example 2: Player has two O's diagonally (positions 0 and 4). They play '[8]' to complete the diagonal and win the game.

Example 3: Early in the game, player chooses '[4]' to take the center position, which gives the most strategic options for creating multiple winning threats.

Example 4: Player sees opponent controls center and one corner. They take the opposite corner '[8]' to prevent opponent from creating a fork.

Format your move as '[number]' where number is 0-8.
